thread.title: The Morning Download: Blockchain, 3-D Printing May Converge in Supply Chain

author: Tom Loftus
title: The Morning Download: Blockchain, 3-D Printing May Converge in Supply Chain
text:
0 COMMENTS A 3-D printed tire from French manufacturer Michelin is on display during the 2018 North American International Auto Show in Detroit, Jan. 16, 2018. Photo: Agence France-Presse/Getty Images
Sign up here for The Morning Download, and get the most important news in business technology emailed to you each weekday morning. Subscribe to WSJ Pro Cybersecurity for in-depth coverage on cybersecurity trends, breaches and best practices. Good morning, CIOs. If one mega tech trend combines with another, what do you call the ensuing marketplace development? A hyper mega trend? We may find out, as blockchain technology and 3-D printing converge in the supply chain. CIO Journal’s Steven Norton has details from the Consensus 2018 conference.
3-D printers could use blockchain to provide audit trail. Just as blockchain can be used to determine the provenance of the romaine lettuce on your plate, it might one day help manufacturers certify and trace 3-D-printed parts through their supply chains. At Tuesday’s Consensus 2018 conference in New York, 3-D printing manufacturers and experts provided scenarios where the distributed ledger technology could create an immutable data source that identifies 3-D-printed parts down to the machine that made them, the technician who worked with them, and the atmospheric conditions under which they were produced.
“Right now it takes companies months to go through papers to distill where the fault is,” said James Regenor, business unit director for transformative technologies at Moog Inc ., which manufactures systems and components in the aerospace, defense and industrial sectors, among others. A distributed ledger could create a trusted — and ideally unbiased — source of information for manufacturers and their customers throughout the supply chain.
TECHNOLOGY NEWS
Trump signs executive order to modernize federal IT. In a fact sheet, the White House said that Tuesday’s executive order will increase the ability of agency CIOs to “influence decision making across bureaus and drive an enterprise-wide view of IT.” The Journal’s John D. McKinnon shines a light on the state of federal IT.
The problem the EO addresses. According to critics, much of $90 billion spent annualy on IT is put toward maintaining costly and duplicative legacy systems that are often 10 to 20 years out of date. See IRS .
Case study. The Department of Agriculture until recently has had 22 chief information officers. It’s in the process of reducing that number to one.
Winners. Major players in cloud and software services, including International Business Machines Corp ., Microsoft Corp. , Oracle Corp. and Amazon.com Inc.
Losers. Suppliers of hardware and IT consulting that have sold legacy IT products and services to the government.
White House eliminates top cyber role. Politico reports that security experts are criticizing a move by National Security Advisor John Bolton to eliminate the White House’s top cyber policy role.
Suspect identified in CIA Vault 7 breach . The New York Times reports that the Federal Bureau of Investigation has identified a suspect in the theft of top secret Central Intelligence Agency documents, including hacker tools, that were later released by WikiLeaks in 2017. The individual is a 29-year-old former CIA software engineer and malware designer.
Verizon names AWS ‘preferred cloud provider.’ Verizon Communications Inc. plans to move 1,000 of its apps and database systems to Amazon Web Services, ZDNet reports . The announcement comes days after low-cost airline Ryanair DAC said that was going “all-in” on AWS, SiliconAngle reports .
Facebook throws cash at stamping out bad content. The company says it is hiring 10,000 people by the end of the year to work on safety and security issues including content review, roughly doubling the total in place this past fall. The WSJ’s Deepa Seetharaman has more .
Graphic violence up. The number of Facebook posts showing graphic violence rose in the first three months of 2018, Reuters reports .
Twitter tweaks algos to tackle abuse. The new change targets accounts that show numerous signs of what Twitter views as bad conduct, including failure to confirm the account-holder’s email address and repeatedly having tweets blocked or muted by others.
Bitcoin exchange welcomes high-speed traders. Coinbase, which operates the largest U.S. cryptocurrency exchange, said it would upgrade its systems with services that cater to ultrafast traders, the Journal’s Alexander Osipovich reports .
Who has the most self-driving permits in California? Apple Inc. , according to Fortune , with 55 self-driving permits. A little more than a year ago, Apple had zero permits. Alphabet Inc. ’s Waymo has 51 self-driving car permits.
When $100 billion is not enough. SoftBank Group Corp.’ s near-$100 billion Vision Fund has yet to close, but CEO Masayoshi Son is already talking sequel, the Journal’s Mayumi Negishi reports . It won’t launch in six months, he said, but it will “in the near future.”
Australian company unveils world’s-largest 3-D printer. The FT reports that Titomic’s bus-sized printer can print complex airplane wing parts up to 9 meters in length.
Lawmakers say U.S. tech used in abusive Chinese crackdowns. Sen. Marco Rubio of Florida and Rep. Chris Smith of New Jersey are urging the Commerce Department to consider toughening export controls on U.S. companies whose technologies they say are being used for state surveillance of citizens in China, the Journal’s Dan Strumpf and Natasha Khan report . A letter penned by the congressmen zeroes in on technology used in Xinjiang province and made by Thermo Fisher Scientific Inc. , a Waltham, Mass.-based manufacturer of laboratory equipment
Agile huddles go corporate. Some 25% of employers are placing at least some employees in unassigned seating, and 52% of the rest plan to do so within three years, according to a recent survey of employers by the real estate services firm CBRE and CoreNet Global.
Fewer desks, more wipes. For a view of the future, the WSJ’s Sue Shellenbarger visits the Minneapolis offices of architecture firm Perkins + Will, which shifted to unassigned seating two years ago, offering 52 adjustable sit-stand desks for the 70 employees there. “Anyone who leaves a desk for more than two hours is expected to pack up and wipe it down with sanitary wipes from one of several office-supply carts,” she writes.
EVERYTHING ELSE YOU NEED TO KNOW
A senior North Korean official accused Washington of trying to “impose on our dignified state the destiny of Libya or Iraq,” casting doubt on the June summit . (WSJ)
Tom Wolfe, the best-selling alchemist of fiction and nonfiction who wrote “The Bonfire of the Vanities,” “The Right Stuff” and countless other novels and works of journalism, died of pneumonia. He was 88 years old. (WSJ)
U.S. forces are preparing for a battle with Islamic State over a valley that was once the Afghan hub of the group’s campaign to create a world-wide caliphate. (WSJ)
Executives at Walt Disney have discussed bringing animation guru John Lasseter back to the company in a new role that would reduce his managerial power but allow him to retain creative influence. (WSJ)
